newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak government replaces deputy finance minister.
newsitem.headline: Slovak government replaces deputy finance minister.

text.p: The Slovak government said on Tuesday it had replaced Deputy Finance Minister Jozef Magula, a sharp critic of recent changes to the securities law, with an economic advisor of Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar.
A government statement said Magula will be replaced by Peter Stanek. It gave no further details.
"I offered my resignation at the end of last year, mainly due to my opposition to some of the latest changes on the capital market," Magula told Reuters.
Magula criticised the amendment to the securities law, approved by parliament in December, saying it harmed transparency on the country's capital market.
The new law forces trading of registered shares onto accredited bourses.

But the law, which had been sent back to parliament by President Michal Kovac for revision, omitted a controversial clause which would have allowed major shareholders to arbitrarily cancel trade in an issue.
In addition to barring trading outside officially registered markets, the new law also forbids changes of registered shares into bearer shares, which was permitted under the previous law.
